text.p: The stock of Hewlett-Packard Co. fell sharply Friday as disappointed investors reacted to the computer company's weaker-than-expected earnings.
The stock skidded $6.125 to $52.75 following a delayed opening on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Palo Alto, Calif.-based maker of computers and printers said after the market closed Thursday that its earnings rose 8 percent in its second fiscal quarter to $784 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $723 million, or 69 cents a share, in the year-ago period.
Revenue for the quarter ended April 30 was $10.3 billion, up 5 percent from $9.9 billion in last year's second quarter.

However, the results were below industry analysts' estimates of 80 cents a share. The company said a tough comparison with last year's strong quarter, the effect of a stronger dollar and slowing in some markets, especially the United States, hampered its growth rate.

Industry analysts cited weaker-than-expected growth in Hewlett-Packard's inkjet printer business and a decline in orders and revenue for its LaserJet printers. The company said overall U.S. orders fell 2 percent during the quarter, while orders outside the United States rose by 7 percent.
Before the market opened, Alex.Brown said it downgraded Hewlett-Packard's stock to market underperform from market perform.
